Posts.Content: Hi Nicky When my mum had breast cancer she didn't want to go through radiotherapy, so she opted for a mastectomy (no reconstruction) and subsequently had no further treatment other than Tamoxifen for 5 years, 11 years on and she is perfectly fine and happy with her decision. I was diagnosed with breast cancer in August 2016, I asked for a mastectomy and was told it was caught early and there was no need for a mastectomy as the overall statistcs don't show much of a difference in survival rates between a lumpectomy and mastectomy. I subsequently had the WLE and was really pleased with the result, no-one would have known I had had an operation once the scar healed - however I had no clear margins so back in again, where they also, as well as the invasive cancer, found extensive DCIS which hadn't shown up on any scans etc. So back in again, clear margins but not enough for the guidelines so after my chemo (mine was HER2+, no lymph nodes so only had it so I could have the Herceptin used to treat this type) I had a mastectomy, with immediate implant reconstruction. I was so pleased to have the breast removed at this point, and I am still happy with the implant, but looking back I wish the WLE had been a success, I have a permanent reminder that I have had breast cancer and I just want to move on, yet every time I look in the mirror my nipple less implant breast is there. So it is a personal decision, but also just be aware that things don't always go to plan, 20% of WLE's result in further operations, but obviously that means 80% don't. There was no cancer detected in my removed breast either ... Hope you have found an answer to your decision, it is so difficult when you are still dealing with the diagnosis! Jo x

Posts.Title: Travelling abroad

Posts.Content: Hello For me, I was really lucky and had a stream of family of friends who helped with various things, but not everyone has this. There are a few practical things to consider getting to and from the hospital and/or GP for blood tests - some areas have a free charity service that takes people to and from their treatment. I would also find out where you can go for your blood tests, and if you can have them at your GP see if they will come out and take them, or if they can arrange district nurses to pop in and see you, so contact your GP and local cancer charities, speak to your consultants team and work out ways to make these medical things as easy as possible. will your daughter be okay ? do you have anyone she can stay with if you end up in hospital at any time (this is just as a back-up, but again something less to worry about and will probably not happen!) you won't know how you will be until you start, everyone is so different. I was really glad to have someone with me whilst I had my treatment, but others prefer to be on their own, do you have anyone who could come along for a session with you ? Or again see if your hospital has volunteers who will buddy up with you ? try and make sure you have everything prepared at home, lots of shopping in, arrange for online deliveries, try and minimise the amount of time you have to be doing things, if you can afford it get in a cleaner for a bit. That way if you don't feel great you don't have the stress of having to do things, and if you feel okay you can spend your time resting and doing things you want to do, as opposed to ones you have to do. make sure your hospital and GP know you are on your own, my GP was great and couldn't do enough for me, but just make an appointment and ask them what they can offer you in terms of care if you don't feel great ? if you are thinking of getting a wig, get one before you start, trying on wigs when your hair is coming out is dreadful ... keep on the Macmillan Forum, and if you put where you are in the country someone may be able to buddy up with you who is going through similar things ? You will get through it, the treatment is doable, not always great fun (!) but doable. Jo x

Posts.Content: Hi My mum had exactly the same as you - 11 years ago - and has had no recurrance. I was diagnosed 16 months ago , mine was ER+ and HER2+ , but aapart from the HER2+ the same as you. I had no scans or anything , as there would be such a small likelihood of anything having spread that it is not a recommended path under the NICE guidelines , so I think you are unlikely to be be able to have them, unfortunately costs do come into consideration with all of this too. I saw an oncologist for the HER2+ part but to be honest I never had any problems and it was just a tick in a box , there was no magic words from them any different from the surgical teams.  After a year I had my mammogram on my healthy boob (which seems pointless to me to have these every year due to the small likelihood of recurrance) and saw the registrar oncologist who just said, basically , bye.  In terms of cancer coming back, having clear scans doesn't mean it won't come back, it just means it's not there at the time and visible. It is one of those diseases where there is a sliding scale of treatment , and some people need every type of treatment to help stop it spreading and coming back , others , like yourself and my mum, only need the minimum involvement- and like LL says, the hormone treatment can be and is,  extremely successful.  Have you looked at the Breast Cancer Care website ? They have a very good helpline which matches you with a volunteer  who has had a similar diagnosis and you can talk to them. They also do an excellent course called Moving Forward which may help you too to come to terms with things going forward ?  Best wishes Jo x

Posts.Content: Hi Mandy i didn't have the cold cap (I had weekly Taxol for 12 weeks) weekly patients aren't offered it at my hospital, my hair was very long so I had mine cut short , and then shorter again . Most of it (but not all) fell out and I wore a wig until about 8 weeks after my treatment ended - I ended up going out without the wig on to fill the car up with petrol and then realising I had no head covering ..., but I just carried on as normal , nobody much looked at me and it was fantastically liberating and I ditched the wig straight away .Before my diagnosis I used to joke with my husband that if I ever ended up in a coma he needed to make sure my hair was dyed and looking lovely. Now my hair is growing back a lot , but is very grey but do you know what I am no longer bothered ! It will grow more and I will dye it again (probably more highlights) but I won't ever have it as long again. So I'm saying this really to try to make you feel better if you decide to ditch the cold cap - it is not the end of the world , losing my eyelashes and my nails was far worse and there's nothing I could have done about that .... It is important to do what you feel is right and not be swayed by others , however well meaning. You have breast cancer and that's a big deal , we all try and protect everyone else which is okay , but you also need to make sure that you look after yourself mentally and physically and only you know how to do that.  Very best wishes for the rest of your treatment , and hope you feel a bit better soon . jo xx

What I would say is to not think about it just yet , get over your first chemo and just see how you feel as you get nearer to it.  I think for me I didn't want to be a victim and didn't want people to look at me and feel sorry for me , whilst I was having chemo the strictly come dancing stars came to visit - most people were happy to see them and had photos etc , I just wanted the floor to open up and swallow me, i didn't want their pity and the tilted head talking to ... that's my problem not theirs , they gave up their time and I'm sure a visit to a chemo ward was not top of their list if of things to do either ,  and most people were very buoyed up by it. So whilst no one can tell you what to do , and what works for one doesn't always work for another , just give yourself a bit of space to clearly think about it x With love jo x

Posts.Content: Hi Everything to do with diagnosis and treatment is very complex, but very basically the stage of the cancer is  stage 0 DCIS or precancerous  stage1 tumour less than 2cm and no node involvement Stage 2 tumour bigger than 2cm but less than 3 cm no node involvement  Stage 3 tumour bigger than 3 cm and any node involvement  There are various shades of grey with this and it isn't used as much now in the UK, as all these stages are treatable and  treatment also depends on other things such as age and type of tumour. Mine was graded as stage 1 grade 2 but changed after my lump was removed to stage 2 grade2 (as was slightly bigger and just into the stage 2 area)but it made no difference to my treatment.  Your ultrasound and scan will have given them the stage part for now , the biopsy the grade, but your treatment will be tailored to you as well as the cancer. Good luck Jo x

Posts.Content: Hi JoJo I think as you have some node involvement that pushes you to stage 3, however I do think some consultants are reluctant to use these staging bands anymore , as particularly for someone like yourself where the neo-adjuvant chemo is so successful, the stage becomes no longer appropriate - stage 4 unfortunately is always stage 4 , the other stages seem to now be a bit blurry-but in a good way, with new treatments and new techniques it seems appropriate that the “old”way of doing things should also change. I have had a couple of glasses of prosecco tonight so hope that makes sense! Jo x
Posts.Title: Newly Dignosed

Posts.Content: Hi As JoJo said, it is difficult to properly advise but if your sister is having chemo and has surgery planned (or has had surgery) she is likely to be stage 3 -  at stage 4 surgery is usually not an option. Some treatments can affect your heart , either the chemo or if her cancer is HER2+ the Herceptin given for this type can affect the heart and make you breathless ( i had this) so she will have heart scans to monitor if she has any problems (i had 5) but most of these side effects are temporary. If she is stage 3 it is very treatable and there are so many different treatments nowadays - no guarantees but there are many women on this site who were/are stage 3 and absolutely fine now.  Stage 4 is still often treatable for many years but isn’t curable, my aunt is stage 4 and now 3 years since her diagnosis with spread to her bones and lungs and she is fine, so please don’t panic too much ! Hope this helps you a bit,and if you get any more information someone will be able to help advise you. Jo x

Posts.Content: Hi Sandy I was due to have a mastectomy with DIEP reconstruction last year (April) but having had 3 operations and chemo I decided it was just too much at that time. I had a mastectomy with an immediate implant instead, I had the operation on the Thursday and came out of hospital on the Friday morning. Posts.Content: Hi The fear and horror is part of the shock and bewilderment that all of us experience , you have been plunged into a world you never wanted to be in , don't understand and full of medical terminology that is scary and difficult to fathom out.  Someone has said before on this forum to just allow yourself a half hour a day to be scared/bewildered/frightened etc , whether that's before you get up in a morning or when you go to bed at night,  and try and carry on the rest of your day as normal , knowing you have got a time to think about things , come on these forums etc. Also write things down , start a diary which is a good way to slot your thoughts together , and also write down questions for the professionals.  There are so many fantastic treatments for breast cancer , which you will find out about as you go through your treatment. I am one year from diagnosis and look back with wonder at what terrible times I had but also there has been lots of good come out of it, and there is no reason that you won't be the same.  There is fantastic support on this forum , you will always find someone who will try and help you Jo xx

Posts.Content: Hi there ,I can't personally help you as I have no idea about these things , however I was speaking to a lady a few weeks ago who had had secondaries ( and had had for a number of years) and she had had various different treatments during that time - but she had only recently been in touch with the local hospice and wishes she had done so before ,she said the pharmacist was fantastic and looked at everything she was taking and sorted her out completely  - so I wouldn't rule them out in favour of your GP necessarily? Just thought I would throw that in in case it helped x Jo x

You can get a new passport with a new photo but you have to pay for it by the looks, probably see how you go ? Jo x
Posts.Title: Passport Photo

Posts.Content: Hi worried , I drove myself mad with all the "information" , most of which contradicts each other to some extent or another , I've pretty much stopped drinking , but that's due to me having weekly chemo and I feel it's too much of an added burden for my body to cope with at the moment , my oncologist did suggest vitamin D and I have been taking this for about two months now - there does seem to be evidence that this can help , but like a lot of these things there isn't enough research into why some people get a recurrence and some don't , and what some people take or don't take, I do try and eat as many veg and fruit as possible , and a few nuts (almonds and Brazil's) a day, but who knows if this will make a difference or not ? But at least I feel I am being pro-active ....  Hope this helps Jo x

Posts.Title: Changes to diet

Posts.Content: Hi Dawn There are so many things to factor in and it is so hard trying to make potentially life changing decisions when you are still in shock from it all. My mum was diagnosed 12 years ago when she was 69 , similar diagnosis although she was very small busted, and there were no where near as many trials , treatments then. She decided to just opt for hormone therapy , she didn't want to go through chemo , and didn't want to run the risk of lympodema either from the auxiliary clearance , she felt that given her age she would enjoy her life with as little medical intervention as possible. She is now almost 81 and fighting fit. Has your mum been offered the oncotype test ? As she is ER+ and miniscule node involvement I would have thought she qualified?  Can you make an appointment with your mums breast care nurse and go with your mum to ask questions ? Get as many questions formulated from looking on this site and see what they say ?  Jo x

I think at the time of your diagnosis you are so intent on other things that the cosmetic side seems a bit demanding when you have had your life saved ! Posts.Content: I finished my chemo on 26th January 2017 and am still having problems with my toenails , another infection in my big one which has grown back very weird (the others are weird , this one is super weird) and my left thumb I think I must also have peripheral neuropathy in , that nail is like concrete - but at least my fingernails on the whole are fine now , ironically I won a manicure in April which I couldn't take up as my nails were too sore  , I darent have them properly done now as I am scared of them hurting - I have moaned about my nails so much to people and they don't get it , everyone on here does so at least I can moan in good company. Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: Hi Lisea I started my post op treatment in 10th November - I saw the oncologist on the 25th October , had a Muga scan on the 2nd November (not sure if you will have had your heart scan yet - you need this before they will consider giving you Herceptin) and 10th November started chemo - combined with blood tests altogether there are lots of things to fit in before you start. My first chemo and Herceptin  was gruelling and I was in the chemo centre for 10 hours - after the Herceptin injection you have to be monitored for 6 hrs before they will give you the chemo part, and before the chemo part you also have steroids , anti-histamines and anti sickness intravenously. My regime is weekly (I was led to believe before seeing the oncologist it would be 4-6 courses every three weeks.  I have my treatment onThursdays, but go for blood tests on the Wednesday morning, except the Herceptin week when I see the consultant on the Tuesday - although I have felt pretty much okay , I really would have struggled time wise to go back to work , I couldn't go Friday as I feel weird , and I have also started to feel really tired - plus as my hair is coming out and I can't have it coloured it looks a complete mess but I don't feel comfortable wearing a wig just yet. I think before the chemo part although I had had three ops the difference to being referred to oncology made me realise the seriousness of the treatment and that was a big shock to me, it really is bizarre isn't it whennyou actually don't feel ill but suddenly everyone is talking about heart scans blood platelet counts etc   The Herceptin jab can sting (not like a normal  injection) and the chemo doesn't hurt , but I have found the whole experience so far to be much more tiring than I thought and I do feel very anxious from Tuesday onwards each week.  Hope this helps you ? Another little thing , I have a lovely friend who makes us some homemade soup for me to have when I get in from hospital on Thursday night and this is the best thing ever !  Best of luck with your treatment, and enjoy your festivities!  Jo x

Posts.Content: Hi Tracy I went back to work for a couple of weeks after my last op and am now taking holiday this week - I am starting chemo next week and having it every week for 12 weeks so will not be in work whilst I'm having that - for me every time I had an appointment at the hospital it never worked out how I had planned , such as two cavity chest shaves and will now after all that need a mastectomy after the chemo as they are not 100% sure they have got all the DCIS cells out (which they didn't know I had until the lumpectomy) so I would say do whatever you feel like doing , hopefully you will have a smooth journey but be prepared to have to change as you go along.  That's a bit rambling but i would wait for  at least a week before going back to work, just to give yourself the best chance of things healing well. Jo x

Posts.Title: I'm not allowed reconstructive surgery because my BMI is to high

Posts.Content: Hi  I was similar to you and unfortunately the Tamoxifen caused me major flushes and general hotness (not in a good way!) my oncologist recommended evening primrose oil , which I do take , and has prescribed a low dose anti-depressant (think it is citlatreprolin or something like that ) if I need it ,however I don't really want to take anything else if I can help it. I did do a course of acupuncture at my local cancer charity , it might be worth looking to see if there is anything on offer at yours ? I have found trying not to be too hot stops some of the flushes ,when I was Christmas shopping I went straight from work , and found I was dripping in sweat once I had walked from work to the shops - I looked like I was having some kind of drug sweat , very unattractive. I do think though the exercise helps , and I am going to try and start walking at night before I go to bed. I also wear pyjamas in bed , as I found my lower legs really sweated and stuck together ,so that helps a bit. I am now a year down the line and wish I could offer you more help ! X Jo x

Posts.Title: Sheffield area- play about women with breast cancer who find support...

Posts.Content: Hi there If you are triple negative you won't be offered Herceptin or Tamoxifen , these are for HER2+ and ER+ respectively , although I do believe some post-menopausal women are being offered the post-menopausal version , called AI inhibitors , for HER2+ breast cancer.  I am not sure how far you are at the moment with your diagnosis , but I am currently on Herceptin (waiting for the injection as we speak) after having 12 lots of chemotherapy, as I am HER2+. I am also ER+ so am also on Tamoxifen.  I know the thought of all these drugs is horrifying , but the reality tends not to be. I saw my oncologist yesterday and the Tamoxifen is doing its job and my oestrogen is almost zero. I do however have flushes and have not slept a full night for months due to hot sweats in bed, and hopefully will be taking something else soon to sort this out.  BUT I am still alive and I would rather be where I am than refusing treatment, but we all have a choice at the end of the day and you do not have to have the treatment they offer , some people don't and I completely respect that.  Dont be panicked by the thought of the treatments , just take one step at a time. best wishes Jo x
Posts.Title: Triple positive - is chemo necessary?

Posts.Content: Hi I can completely sympathise with you . I was diagnosed with an invasive lump in Aug 2017 , had WLE but no clear margins , 2nd op also uncovered extensive DCIS , still no clear margins, so third op - still no guarantee of clear margins so I ended up with a mastectomy. My breast looked fine through all the WLE's , so I wouldn't worry too much about how it looks, they do just remove small areas.  Mine is not the norm, most people have success after the 2nd op , and I have to say I was extremely upset after the 2nd failed op, but in the end just glad it was all removed. The pathology of my mastectomy showed no cancer , so in effect I was clear after the third one but they just didn't know that and I was glad to be rid of it - however if you can keep your breast I would. Hope your second op goes well and you get good news then Jo xx
Posts.Title: Second surgery following lumpectomy and SNB

Posts.Content: I think it depends on lots of different factors (like everything else associated with breast cancer!) Diffevent consultants /hospitals have different ideas for a start ..,. I had weekly Taxol and had cannulas fitted each time - became a bit of a pain trying to find a vein particularly towards the end , but it meant no other inetervention was needed, so don't worry about it , whatever they suggest can always be changed. Best of luck with the chemo , I was unbelievably anxious , I couldn't even go to visit the chemo Ward before my treatment , but the actual process was nothing like I feared , just make sure you do as they tell you in regard to aftercare.  Jo x

Posts.Title: Help with hot flushes

Posts.Content: Sorry I read it wrong ! Please don't panic about the results , easy to say but I was diagnosed 11 months ago with a 1.8 cm tumour , grade 1 stage 1 which once I had surgery became 2.1 cm and grade 2 stage 2. They also uncovered extensive grade 3 DCIS which was about to become invasive, so I ended up having a mastectomy and implant reconstruction after my chemo.  if you just take one step at a time , the not knowing and waiting for results is the most nerve wracking part , and nothing anyone says will make that bit easier - but the treatment is all do able andI am so thankful now that I am still alive , when you have breast cancer you are not normally ill, so getting your head around the fact that you are going to have treatment which will make you feel worse in the short term is mind boggling , along with all the medical terminology and decisions we have to make fairly quickly.  This site is great for getting information , reassurance and seeing how other people go on with their breast cancer , so just post a discussion and someone will be along to answer your query , no matter how big or small it is. Jo xx
Posts.Title: Triple positive - is chemo necessary?

Posts.Content: I would most definitely go back and ask for a referral to a breast clinic - I had pain off and on in one of my breasts for a few months - then found a lump which was invasive breast cancer , along with extensive DCIS - if I had gone before I felt the lump I may not be where I am now , and as others have said why pain is not mentioned on things to look out for I am not sure - it is most definitely best to be safe than sorry, some cancers can be fast growing and aggressive but no one knows this until the lump has been biopsies or removed.  Best wishes jo x
Posts.Title: Breast pain - what would you do?

Posts.Content: Hi Jo You may not end up losing your lashes , mine thinned and so did my eyebrows , but I kept some of them - but I think sometimes the thought is worst than the reality ! Mine have taken a while to grow back properly, but it was my nails which distressed me the most , and my toenails fell off 5 months after I had finished chemo!  My friend has alopecia and always looks fab , just down to makeup.  Looking back at photos of me before during and just after treatment really shocked me , but at the time I just accepted it. Losing my hair was actually liberating , and I decided to keep it short and silver fox , but have realised that every time I look at myself I am reminded of the cancer and I now need to properly move on - my last Herceptin is due 8th November and (apart from the possibility of ovary removal and tablets) will be the end of treatment and  I am looking forward to it so much - not sure what to do with the hair yet , bizarrely losing it was okay , it's it growing back that's caused me more problems !  Hope you are soon back home and hope you are feeling a bit better. Jo x
Posts.Title: how long did it take for your hair to fall out on EC?

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy I am on Tamoxifen (52 years old) and expected to be switched to an AI sooner rather than later, however my oncologist said that there is research that keeping on Tamoxifen for a number of years and then switching after about 4-5 years has the best chance of you not becoming resistant to one drug, the oncologists know about all of this research before we get to hear about it (they may have even had a part in it) Hope this helps Jo x

Posts.Content: I think it is just a trial and will then be rolled out to the rest of the country - it’s just for people with non-specific symptoms, suspected cancer with specific symptom will all still be dealt with as now, generally the diagnosis and treatment of the cancers I have had dealings with (me, family and friends) have been fantastic, but maybe where someone has general symptoms such as losing weight which could indicate lots of different things, they will go through  this system, rather than being passed from one specific cancer specialist to another ?
Posts.Title: Cancer One Stop Shops Information

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda (hope that's your name) When I've had my operations I wore the usual hospital gown , kept my underwear on and was given a pair of compression stockings to wear. I also had my dressing gown on and walked down to the theatre. I took off my dressing gown and laid on an operating bed , where I slipped my arms out but was still covered up, but meant it was easier for them to move during the operation . Then injection from the anaesthetist and next thing woke up in recovery.  It was all done completely sensitively, everyone was completely lovely, it is still an operation but please don't worry , these are usually done as day cases too. Where I had mine they also tested my lymph nodes whilst I was under , and if there was cancer in there would have removed all of them - luckily for me there was no spread to the lymphs so I didn't need this procedure.  If you have any queries or questions , don't worry about them just post them on here and someone will answer them. Bedt wishes Jo x
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: Hello There is the nhs predict tool which you can also use which gives the level of extra expected chance  of recurrance with your treatment - I am HER2+ and ER+ and the Tamoxifen I am on will only give me an increase of about 2/3% , but as I was 51 when diagnosed I feel I need to take it , at least in the short term , unfortunately there are many ladies who take the medication but still get recurrance - there are no guarantees ! However the earlier caught and the lower the grade gives a very good indication that recurrance is very, very low risk.  Your consultant should also be able to give you statistics , there does seem to be a movement away from these drugs by women who have debilitating side effects and would just rather take the risk and enjoy their lives. Hope you get some answers Jo xx
Posts.Title: I don't understand my prognosis/what my future is

Posts.Content: Hi there i am also ER+ and HER2+ , I had weekly Paclitaxel, or Taxol, and was okay , you do get hair loss and there are other possible side effects and I wouldn't say it was easy , but it was very do-able. Posts.Title: Should I be switched from tamoxifen to a aromatase inhibitor post...

Posts.Content: Hi i know it’s easy to say don’t panic , but what I would say is that this site is mainly for women who are awaiting results or who get diagnosed with breast cancer - so the majority of women who are referred for further tests and don’t have breast cancer aren’t on here to answer your question, so it may be that you get one or two answers of yes, but in the actual scheme of things these are a minority ? So , worst case scenario you have a breast cancer diagnosis - it can be devastating but breast cancer is generally very, very treatable these days,, the treatments can be not what you would ever put on your bucket list , but all doable.  So try not to panic too much, and hopefully you will get good news. jo x
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Referral

Posts.Content: Hi worried , I drove a little after my WLE and two further cavity shaves , main problem I had was the seatbelt sat just where my scar was so it was uncomfortable- I did the exercises religiously and they definitely helped,  particularly the ones which involve lifting your arm over your head - have you got an appointment with physio ? They were really helpful in explaining things , she suggested before getting up in the morning bringing my arm across my body (as if it was broken and in a pot) and then lifting that over my head -  apparently this is a good one to do if you are going on to have radiotherapy as this is the position you may need to adopt whilst having it - not sure if you are having radiotherapy and I am not now but someone else may be able to advise ?  After three ops ( last one end of October) my boob has just settled down but I do still have some thickening at the top , so I think it can take some time for it all to heal properly. Best wishes Joanne
Posts.Title: Tell me about your scars

Posts.Content: No-one asked me either about the fabric - but I would suggest you go to the loo when they come to collect you and don't wear hold in big knickers which is what I did when I had my mastectomy (and woke up desperate for the loo ...,)  Jo x
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Louise I ended up with a mastectomy with immediate implant on my fourth operation (so should have known better) For some inexplicable reason I put on some massive, hold in pants which came almost up to my boobs, and made the other mistake of not going to the loo at the last minute before I went to theatre - hence I woke up in recovery, desperate for the loo, and having a hot flush, I cannot begin to tell you how uncomfortable I was, my heart was tachy, and I was covered in furry blankets. I ended up having to use a commode but couldn't remove these enourmous pants due to my left side being sore still and drains everywhere - the nurse had to do it for me, and pull them up, it was not an episode I would like to repeat .....but once I had been my heart settled down and I went to the ward .... My hospital fitted me with a bra the next day, the drains are a pain and dictate what you can wear really, but in terms of underwear you should be fine (as long as they are not the hold everything in ones !) Good luck, you will be sore but make sure you do the exercises. Jo x
Posts.Title: Under wear when having surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Just reading your post , have you contacted Macmillan about your finances ? They do offer a one off payment , and can give you lots of advice on what you may be entitled to - also your bank may be help you out with payment breaks for mortgage payments etc. It is worth asking ,the worst they can say is no, I had bank charges refunded by my bank and they were sonlo elyto deal with. Posts.Title: Genetics results - No mutation found

Posts.Content: As far as I am aware there is no monitoring if you have a bilateral mastectomy - there is such a small amount of breasttissue left that scanning is not feasible , and reconstructions are not breasts tissue so  there is nothing to scan there. My friend had a double mastectomy (cancer in both breasts) and had a MRI scan of the breast area to be used if she developed any problems in the future , but had no other subsequent monitoring.  I had a mastectomy 8 months ago and was desperate to be rid of it , I also asked for a double mastectomy as none of the precancerous DCIS showed up on any scans, they didn't say no but suggested I have a think about it.  Now though I miss my breast , sexually things are very different and I don't want the other one removing , so I would just say a bit of distance does definitely help you make your mind up one way or the other, and I do understand why counselling is recommended, when you are in the middle of all the treatment it may not be the best time to make a decision. Jo x
Posts.Title: Bilateral mastectomy (and pain in healthy breast)

Posts.Content: Hi Louise I had three failed lumpectomy operations , then chemo so it was 7 months before I had my mastectomy , I was going to have the diep flap but couldn't bear the thought of a long operation and another part of my body being cut open , having to make such big decisions when you are just diagnosed is really hard , even though I had time to think I wonder if I did the right thing in the long term. I am contemplating going back for the other side to be lifted as I have one pert boob and one saggy one ! Good idea about the drains , - in terms of laughter , we know we are in a potentially very serious position , but I have always found laughter to be a good medicine for me , I have had some ludicrously hilarious moments this last 15 months , am now though the other side and enjoying every minute.  Good luck Jo xx
Posts.Title: Under wear when having surgery

Posts.Content: Hi I found the sentinel node biopsy the worst part - the lumpectomy my surgeon did a fab job , no one would have even noticed once it had settled. You really must do the exercises they give you. I ended up with no clear margins but would be interesting to see now there is more chemo done before surgery on the "failure" rate (I was quoted that 20 % don't have clear margins) These things are the reason why they just give you a bit of treatment plan at a time , until they operate they don't know for definate about lymph nodes, clear margins and vascular invasion. When I was diagnosed I had already worked out when I would be having various treatments , but it never worked out like that! Two weeks after the op I was okay , but mine was my left boob and my main problem was the seatbelt was really uncomfortable. After my third op I went to a charity ball and dinner the next night  , can't say it was the best night I ever had but was determined I wouldn't let my diagnosis stop me doing everything ( I ended up cancelling so many things , holidays , masters degree, conference in Norway...)  Good luck ,do what they say and you will be fine. Jo xx
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy questions...

Posts.Content: Hi Just to add to this, I was originally diagnosed with ER+ & HER2+ invasive breast cancer, which I was told would need chemo for. When they operated they found lots of DCIS, but I was told they don't test for HER2+ in DCIS as it is not applicable, they do test for ER/PR though, so all my treatment (apart from surgery ) was guided on the invasive part. Cheers Joanne
Posts.Title: Hi I've just been diagnosed with dcis I'm 31 and am awaiting an op...

Posts.Content: Hi wsarahw, I am exactly at this phase hair wise , I have very thick hair so noeone would even know at the moment but I have had to hoover our bedroom every day for the last 3 days ( and I'm not houseproud!) and the hair shower is hideous ! I have just texted my friend to ask her to come and crop mine , I'm not sure how I will feel after but it has to go - how are you feeling a few days down the line ? Jo x
Posts.Title: Braved the Shave

Posts.Content: Hi Tilla has given you some great tips, i would also ask about whether you will keep your nipple, and if not if they can reconstruct. Also if they will do anything with your remaining breast to even you up ? Also practicalities of the operation, how long will you be in, will you be fitted with a bra, will you have the drains changed by district nurses etc. these are all individual to the area you live. I had a mastectomy with immediate implant last year as I had already had three failed WLE's,  and just couldn't face a long operation - however I am waiting to be referred to the clinic to discuss having a diep flap, but due to cost cutting I may not be able to have it - another thing to factor in, that you may only get the one shot at it now ? Good luck Jo x
Posts.Title: Questions to ask re: mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi I am on Tamoxifen, and although I am not suffering from depression I had horrible hot flushes which I put up with for a year. My oncologist told me not to take anything not prescribed, with the exception of Evening Primrose Oil and  had prescribed Citalopram (had sent the details to my GP)  and I started taking those, however they didn't agree with me ( complete loss of feelings) but my GP changed me to Setraline. These have vastly improved my quality of life, I didn't realise how much my life was affected before. So I would suggest going to see your GP, mine has been really helpful. Best wishes Jo x
Posts.Title: Taking anti-depressants or St John’s Wort with letrozole

Posts.Content: Hi Not quite the same but I had no clear margins, had two more cavity chest shaves , and still needed a mastectomy - to say I was gutted is an understatement, however time passes and you just adjust and get on with what comes next. What I have learnt is that things often don’t go as planned, and I do wish they would emphasise that more than they do.It doesn’t mean that the outcome will be bad, just a different way of getting to the right result. just take a deep breath and get ready for your next op - have you got a date yet ? X Jo x
Posts.Title: Second Operation

Posts.Content: Hello I have been so lucky to have fantastic support from my family and friends - one of the positives to come out of my breast cancer is how lucky I am to have this. Some of my friends cooked for me and my family , bringing around lasagnes , curries , fish pies , cakes - you name it we've had it. This was a godsend when I had my operations and during my weekly chemo (one friend makes us homemade soup each week) I have had numerous flowers , gifts , lovely toiletries etc, so anything you can do for her would be so much appreciated. The one thing I have been most humbled by is the text messages and words of encouragement I get from some people , often those not closest to me. I know it is impossible to know what your friend is going through , but by being interested and letting her know you care in whatever way you think will, I'm sure be very much appreciated. Well done for being a lovely friend  Jo x
Posts.Title: Procedure

Posts.Content: Hi My mum was 69 when she had her mastectomy , so not as old as your mum but still not young- she coped really well. I had a mastectomy 2 years ago aged 51 and I was just in overnight - your mum may need to stay in longer as she is having a double. What she will have is drains which are huge, my district nurse came every day to monitor them until they were removed on day 6. I never needed any pain relief, but it can be very uncomfortable, plus having a general anaesthetic will take it’s toll.  I would say two weeks should be okay, but it is difficult to say as everyone reacts so differently.As Ronstar says the exercises are really important, and it may be useful for your mum to do them before she goes into hospital to familiarise herself and also to see if she can actually do them - if you google breast cancer exercises you should find them ( there may also be some on the Macmillan site)  best wishes Jo x
Posts.Title: Supporting my elderly Mum

Posts.Content: Hi there I was very similar to you , had a lump and when it was removed had no clear margins and they found DCIS lurking in there - I ended up having two further ops to try and remove it - the last one I only had as I could have the operation done the next day , a mastectomy I would have had to wait a bit longer for, so thought I may as well give it a go - still no clear margins so I had a mastectomy. I had no node involvement but my cancer was HER2+ so needed chemo , so had my mastectomy after the chemo, I was going to have a diep flap reconstruction but by the time it came to it I had had enough and decided on an implant instead. When they did the pathology on my breast there was no cancer left ... but I'm glad I had it done. Jo x
Posts.Title: Having a mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Miss Wizy I had a mastectomy with immediate permanent implant using the stratice in April, the first few weeks I had some seroma and the drains (enourmous bottles) were a joy but I had already had three failed WLE's and chemotherapy so I think my body was pretty weary at that point ! But I found the recovery to be fine and started going to the gym about 3 months after the operation (could have been sooner if I had wanted to), I think if you are pretty healthy and fit you will recover quicker, so the fact that you run will stand you in good stead. Even now I wear a really tight sports bra for the gym as I just feel more comfortable with it. Personal decision, I was all set for the DIEP (didn't want the back muscle op at all anyway) but realised I really didn't want another part of my body being cut open and also realised I was more interested in having the tummy tuck than the actual boob .... Whatever you decide they are not real, however realistic they look, and my implant looks fine, although a little perkier than my other one (although the surgeon said he is happy to lift that one to match if I want, don't think I am going to bother ) Good luck Jo x
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: Hello I know many people who have had breast cancer over the years, and most of them have had no side-effects from the endocrine drugs, my mum was on Tamoxifen for 5 years some time ago (in her sixties at the time) as there were no AI's then, she had no problems at all with them. I am on Tamoxifen (on the edge of post-menopausal) and have the hot sweats and flushes but nothing else, however I don't see this as a side effect, this is what the drugs are supposed to do, suppress the oestrogen in the body., so I am just investigating various options to alleviate these symptoms. I am 52 and am having more blood tests soon to see if my brain is still trying to kick-start my ovaries, and if it is will be having them removed. I think women around the 50 age group who are probably peri-menopausal are most problematic with these drugs and oestrogen production. Like everything, you need to be aware of possible problems, but people often come on sites like this one when they are having problems, the ones who aren't don't tend to bother, so it may seem that everyone has problems with them when in fact the opposite may be true. Good luck in your choice, as someone else has said why not try it and see how it goes ? Or ask about Tamoxifen which my mum had, today she would be offered AI's instead ? Jo x
Posts.Title: anastrozole and similar

Posts.Content: Hi , mine too was very curly but I had it all chopped off ( and still keep having it short at the moment) but has shown no signs of the curliness anymore (finished chemo January 2017) Jo x
Posts.Title: Hair after chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Minnie I was 51 when I was diagnosed, and am HER2+ and ER+, so had Herceptin and chemo for the HER2+ part. I had a period before I started chemo (Nov 2016) but have had none since.For the ER+, I was prescribed Tamoxifen, and as the chemo had sent me into the early menopause, and given my age, my oncologist told me there would be no need for ovary suppression as my body was unlikely to start sending signals again about kick starting them, so just Tamoxifen. However, when I had a blood test in June it showed the hormone FSH was increasing, so she was concerned that my ovaries may start to work again. I had another blood test in September and it had gone down, however if it had still been going up I would have been offered the Zoladex or ovary removal - so I think it depends where you are in the menopause (or not in it) I am still on Tamoxifen as I am still not fully menopausal (god help me when I am!) but am having the test again in December to doubly make sure. Jo x
Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi From what I remember - it is the same as any pre-op, making sure you are fit enough for the anaesthetic and operation. I had an online test looking at any other medical issues etc and then had blood pressure etc taken , think I was weighed and then had a consultation with a nurse - May have forgotten something but that’s generally it. What operation are you having ? Having a lumpectomy is normally only a day case and you are only under for a short period of time ,an hourish, a mastectomy is usually longer , depending on what reconstruction depends on your recovery etc. The sentinel nodes are also removed in whichever operation and checked for any traces of cancer.  Hope this helps jo x
Posts.Title: Pre op

Posts.Content: I think like Toxophilite and Karen have said , every one is different and I don't dwell on what ifs , I just get on with things , I am so glad I am like that and feel for others who feel so wretched about their situation. So many people have said how well I have coped and how positive I have been but that is just me ,im coping in my way and others cope in theirs, neither is right or wrong , it is just the way we are all so different anyway,so don't feel bad , I like to think that us positive souls can help those who struggle and this site is so very good for that. Jo x
Posts.Title: Abnormal lack of feelings?

Posts.Content: Hi JoJo  I am sure they know what they are doing but I had no break when I had my mastectomy- I had it the day before the op, then the normal theee weeks later.Mine were by injection, but I am unsure why there would need to be a period for you to heal ? Unless it may be to do with your issues with your heart and the potential stress with the anaesthetic ? I would query it , just for peace of mind at least. Jo xx

Posts.Title: Zoladex and tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hi I had my flu jab on the Saturday before my surgery on the following Friday - I had had two failed wles’s and this was my third , I was told there was no problem with having the jab whilst surgery is planned. However things don’t always go to the original plans so I would say have it done as soon as possible - otherwise you may run out of time to have the jab.  My GP won’t inoculate anyone unless they fill a strict criteria - my husband was diagnosed with prostate cancer the month after me and didn’t fulfil the criteria, so no jab. Good luck with your surgery Jo x
Posts.Title: Flu jabs - timing and family as well?

Posts.Content: Hi I'm 52 but was still having periods before chemo - have not had one for a year now , I'm on Tamoxifen and my oncologist said it was unlikely for my periods to start again at my age - however I had a blood tests in June to check my oestrogen level and it also picked up that my body was producing FSH which basically tries to get the ovaries moving again. I had my blood checked again this week and thankfully this is now as expected. If it was still a problem I would have been put forward to have my ovaries removed. I think this only applies if your cancer was ER+ but I would definitely  mention it to your nurse Jo x.
Posts.Title: Chemo induced menopause and then .....

Posts.Content: Hi I am a patient representative at my hospital so it may be worth seeing if yours has a similar group ? But even if the answer is yes it would be unlikely to be done by the 20th July as these things need so much paperwork ,risk assessments etc . Have a word with the staff when you next go about why they haven’t got one, there maybe reasons - I myself wouldn’t have wanted to do it but can understand why people would, however there are some people having chemo who won’t ever ring the bell as they are having palliative treatment and this may be why there is no bell,in order not to cause upset to those patients ?  Jo x
Posts.Title: A Bell To Ring

Posts.Content: Hi The sexual side of breast cancer treatment still seems to be a taboo.i had a mastectomy and implant  and my nipple was removed and it is now over a year later that my husband has said how sad he is about it all, for me but also that that side of our life is no longer the same- we have had a really good chat and as I am having DIEP surgery probably next year- I am going to have a nipple tattoo, I will have to pay for it but the results look fantastic, not the same by any means as a real one but I am happy to do this for us, it is something which affects both of us, not just me, and for me that’s important to recognise.  Best wishes Jo x
Posts.Title: Looking for mastectomy buddy

Posts.Content: Hi Well done for staying positive- the cancer has gone, everything else is to make sure it stays that way! You will have a heart scan due to the Herceptin and this will be repeated every three/four months, you will have 18 injections (sometimes an infusion is given instead), everyone has slightly different chemo , but good luck for your next chapter in your journey. Jo xx
Posts.Title: todays post surgery update

Posts.Content: Hi Andy I had same as you five weeks ago , my new boob is still sore in places (side boob and lower part of cleavage) but nowhere near as sore as it was , but it's only these last few days that it has cleared up so much. I don't have a dint so can't help you with that and in terms of bras I'm still wearing support bras for now, but am waiting for a few weeks before I go and get measured for new ones. I go back to see my surgeon again on the 1st June - he doesn't do uplift on the other boob at the same time as the reconstruction as he says they do drop slightly so prefers to wait and see before lifting the other one. I am planning on just what I would have normally worn on holiday , just got to be a bit more careful after having had chemo. Jo x
Posts.Title: Post mastectomy/reconstruction...Questions

Posts.Content: Hi lindsaybubbles Mine is a similar story to yours , I had a lumpectomy but no clear margins and two subsequent “cavity chest shaves “ still no clear margins , they just kept on finding more of all sorts of stuff which hadn’t shown up on any scans - my lymph nodes were clear , but I needed chemo as mine was HER2+ and needed the chemo to have Herceptin. After this finished I had my mastectomy with an immediate implant, which I was pleased with. The bittersweet news was that no trace of cancer was found in the remaining breast tissue , but to be honest I was glad to be rid of it at the time. I am now awaiting a plastic surgery appointment to have DIEP reconstruction. I was diagnosed exactly 2 years ago tomorrow so it is all a memory but I can still feel the disappointment when things didn’t go to plan- I started a blog at the time entitled Snakes and ladders as that’s how my journey feels it has been. Has  reconstruction been mentioned to you yet ? It is such a hard decision to make, and I think after failed lumpectomies even harder as you have already accepted that you don’t need a mastectomy to then be told you do, with time ticking away too. Please message me if you want any more information and good luck with your treatment. Jo x
Posts.Title: Looking for mastectomy buddy

Posts.Content: I think you really need to speak to your team, I was advised to cancel a conference abroad I was due to attend. If you are going somewhere in this country you may be okay , but flying abroad may mean you are exposed to too many germs ? If you already have insurance for your holiday you need to let them know about your diagnosis , but if not there is a travel insurance thread here on the Macmillan site - I went away after my treatment  and used Boots online. They were really good. If you’ve not seen your oncologist yet, ask your nurse for their phone number and ring them - I rang mine a couple of times and they always got back to me  quickly.   In terms of does it hurt , as others have said it doesn’t , if it does you need to tell them - but the chemo units are generally a quiet place, mine had tv on and you can chat or just be by yourself if you want. My mum came with me to most of mine and came packed up with sandwiches and snacks , the best description of it is really quite boring !  Good luck ,  Jo x
Posts.Title: Is chemotherapy painful?

Posts.Content: Hi Helen I had appointments changed a few times, once when the surgeon was going on holiday, and I also had no clear margins twice, so there is always that possibility, I believe that 20 % of cases this happens. Hopefully it is your surgeon who is wanting the day off and trying to get through the "easy" patients who don't need any more surgery! Good luck Joa x
Posts.Title: Recall early for results from lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Tukis1983, So sorry you have been diagnosed with such a life changing disease at such a young age , I think it is so hard to get your head around to the fact that you probably didn't feel at all ill, but have been given this devastating news along with the whole hospital, appointments, surgery etc - and having surgery is a stark reminder of that as well , particularly, the major surgery you have had. I do think it is also a form of bereavement , mourning our past life - but we do have a life to look forward to as do our children , and that's what I always try and think. I am normally very positive but it hits me at times when things haven't gone to plan or the silliest things - that is completely normal and I think the despair is also from the fact that although we have (without wanting to!) changed our loved ones lives with the diagnosis , we are out of control with being able to fix it , and I think mum's always want to fix things for the better for our children.  My main thought is that I can't change what has happened, the only thing I can really control is how I deal with it , and everyone will have different ways of this. In a couple of days , once you have recovered a bit more from the surgery , you will hopefully regain a bit of perspective again - if you still feel very low you may be better talking to your Dr ?  Much love Jo x
Posts.Title: Feeling deflated

Posts.Content: Hi Spinningrose65 I’ve posted this before but top left is me 8 weeks after my chemo finished, it was a further 8 weeks before I had it cut and con had nearly day that it was about a year before it properly felt back to normal - so don’t despair, it will be back before you know it x  jo x
Posts.Title: Of hair regrowth after chemo ....

Posts.Content: Hi there As others have said , it is most likely from the biopsy and just knowing it's there ! I did offer to go in as a last minute case if a cancellation arose , which it did - I was due my pre-op 9th September and op 16th but got a call late afternoon of the 31st August offering me the op on the 2nd , so pre-op 1st , op 2nd, so may be worth ringing and saying you would be happy to take a cancellation (if you are ) ?  Jo xx

Posts.Title: Nose sores!!

Posts.Content: Sorry but I wonder why you think everyone with breast cancer should get PIP? I have no reason at all to be given it, it has affected my life but not to the extent that I need to pay for help - it isn’t a compensation scheme for those of us unfortunate enough to have had it ? If everyone who has cancer (breast cancer is not special) applied the system would collapse, so only those who really need it should apply, otherwise they will be lost in a system of cases which are not valid. Posts.Title: Does anyone know anything about PIP?

Posts.Content: Hi Lynne You've found a good place to come - none of us on this forum wanted to be here and we all had that same feeling , you are in shock and it will take a while to sink in and your emotions will be all over the place. BUT breast cancer nowadays is very treatable, your medical team will work out what is best for you in regards to treatment - there are many different types of breast cancer and treatment is tailored individually , so don't be alarmed if someone else with a similar diagnosis has different treatments , Leave that to the specialists! Have they given you any idea on what your treatment may be or type of breast cancer ? Jo xx
Posts.Title: Diagnised today.......feel a bit lost!

Posts.Content: Hello In terms of mastectomy , they are very reluctant to do this at anytime, but given you have had your surgery and are now, in effect , cured, they will be very unlikely to do any further surgery unless you have a genetic tendency of the BRACA type. I had a mastectomy and asked about the other one, but even though my mum and aunt have both had breast cancer the answer was there was no need.  Having a mastectomy doesn’t stop it coming back either I’m afraid , there is very little difference between recurrence rates from lumpectomy and mastectomy. Have you asked about counselling ? Your local cancer charity will offer this service, and your breast care nurse will also be able to refer you if needed. I think it is such a shock, and you have had such a whirlwind treatment you probably haven’t had time to properly get your head around the whole situation.  Jo xx
Posts.Title: Chemo - Should I have it or not?

Posts.Content: HiRoundhouse1 I had weekly Paclitaxol, as Leolady said hair loss was, for me after week 3, other side effects were my nails took a battering, fell off months later, became infected etc, this bothered me more than losing my hair. I also had several bleeds of my nose, just dripping with blood, particularly if I had anything hot or spicy. I also developed blisters of hard skin all over my hands - as you can imagine my hands looked delightful! I then developed weird brown patches on my palms too, but they were short lived. Your mum will be given steroids and anti-histamines as the drug can have a very strong reaction if you are allergic, these affected me more than the actual drug. I had a couple of episodes of choking after my treatment ( the same night) but that was when I had eaten something not suitable such as fish and chips. I just ended up having homemade soup and bread on throes treatment nights. One bizarre thing was that I have suffered from a form of dermatitis for years and it cleared up whilst I was on the chemo, and although it has now returned it is much less severe. I have never suffered with any issues from the Herceptin, but we are all different and can all react in different ways. I found it quite gruelling at the time, but doable. It is two years next week when I started my treatment and am now happy, hopefully healthy and enjoying life, your mum will get there too, particularly with support from family and friends, I was really lucky in that and am sure it made a difference. hope this helps jo x
Posts.Title: Weekly Paclitaxel (12 weeks) & herceptin

Posts.Content: Hi Not the same, but when I had my appointment for mammogran/ultrasound and they also took the biopsy, they told me there and then it was cancer and I would be going back the following week for confirmation and my treatment plan - they don't always know fully but they often have a very good indication of what things are, so them saying it looks benign will mean they are pretty certain, but the biopsy results will confirm that  - won't stop you having those niggling doubts though until next week ! Jo x
Posts.Title: Waiting a week for results!!

Posts.Content: Hello Slightly different but my aunt was 82 when she was diagnosed , hers had spread to her lungs and bones, she nearly died of a blood clot and was only diagnosed then. She has just been on medication , and is now 85 and just been on holiday with my mum to Spain for the second time this year ! Her cancer has remained stable , so if the medication works your mum may be absolutely fine.  Hope this helps Jo x
Posts.Title: Elderly Mum diagnosed

Posts.Content: I'm also in the middle of deciding what to do but have ruled out the LD flap - the surgeon asked why I didn't want that , I explained why (all points raised above) and he then said it wouldn't be suitable anyway as I didn't have enough tissue etc there to make a breast , so I would also need some tissue from somewhere else (so three scars !) so why he had suggested it I'm not sure.  I have been offered the DIEP but at this moment am so fed up with hospitals and things going wrong that I am (today at least!) thinking of an implant - the surgeon has said he will lift my other boob at a later date too so the match better.  Such a difficult decision , I would rather there was no decision to make. Jo x
Posts.Title: Having second thoughts about type of reconstruction

Posts.Content: My son told me after he knew I would need chemo that he was going to have his head shaved in our local pub for charity - I felt sick when he told me but didn't want to put him off as he felt strongly about wanting to feel he was doing something, however the next day I sat down with him and told him I didn't really want him to do it , but I understood why he wanted to - I also said that if he wanted to tell people that I really didn't want him to do it that was okay - he decided not to in the end and is taking part in a sponsored run this year with his friends instead - I am much happier with this , and am sat typing this with a very cold bald head !

Posts.Content: Hi eliza44 Ive just had a look and it seems that it is not a recommended scan to determine breast cancer , and it doesn’t seem to be widely used. In terms of the oncotype, the general test is for invasive cancer to determine whether chemotherapy would be useful to stop a recurrence - as DCIS is not invasive it isn’t suitable. There does seem to be some kind of oncotype for DCIS but only where there has been a lumpectomy and it is not covered by NICE as a normal test. i had a similar story to you but my initial lump was invasive, however my breast was pretty much filled with high grade rupturing DCIS which hadn’t shown up on anything. I had my mastectomy two year ago and have now had two clear mammograms on my other breast. Am I confident there is nothing there ? Not completely but I am just ultra vigilant, there is nothing which will give any full peace of mind unfortunately, only that it is possible but it is generally unlikely to have breast cancer in both breasts. Worry about recurrence is something which we all have to live with, I just don’t let it get in the way of living, I can’t change what may or may not happen, however there are some very good counselling services available and you may get some help there ? Also breast cancer care have a Someone like me service and they may be able to put you in touch with one of their volunteers who has had a similar scenario to you. Hope this helps Jo x

The subsequent pathology revealed no cancer or DCIS left.  I was desperate to be rid of my breast and also concerned about the other breast , but they are reluctant to do the double operation or even the single sometimes. I couldn't understand that at all , but now I can. I have a permanent reminder that I had cancer ,I can't help but think about it everyday when I see my breast, and do mourn having a real breast, even though costmetically no one would know when I am wearing clothes. So , other things to bear in mind , if you have a mastectomy they can't scan you as there isn't enough breast tissue left , but you can still get a recurrance as there is always some tissue left ( and research shows that having a mastectomy doesn't give any better outcome in terms of survival)  At the beginning of the process and before I had breast cancer I would have alsways said I would want the breast removed , and I know it was the right decision for me (I couldn't have ever rested knowing there may be cancer left)  but it is a very major thing , so you really need to think carefully about it.  Hope this perspective helps you , Jo xx

Posts.Content: Hi benimar It looks like we are reasonably similar. I was 51 and premenopausal and both  HER2+ and ER+. Posts.Title: Travel insurance (another one!)

Posts.Content: My view is that no-one has found a cure for cancer , it has been around for as long as people have been alive , more people get it now because we all live much longer and we have to die of something ! If there were an easy cure involving plants etc it would have been discovered many many years ago. Modern research is not all funded by drug companies , there is extensive research going on the whole world over by academics, funded by many different sources - and these academics and Drs talk to each other , they don't just read up on something - for them the publication of a paper will be generally something they are already aware of and following - it doesn't just appear from nowhere. I think we all have a responsibility to take some control of our own treatments and question the particular treatment (as we know , pretty much no-one has the same scenario and treatment) we are being offered , I have always known that cancer doesn't just recur , how can it if it's been removed , but the treatment nowadays is to attack as much of the rogue cells as possible or cut off the sources (university of Sheffield is leading a research on LOX cells sent out by breast cancer) with targeted treatments leading the way such as Herceptin- no one has ever said that I will be cured , treatable and hopefully no recurrence , but as I said earlier , there is no cure , just treatment which hopefully works for us , and that is enough to let us lead a long and fulfilled life.  Everyone has to make their own choices, and life is all about having choices - we are lucky in the western world to have choices and access to first rate care , some people don't have that luxury. Jo x
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi As others have said, most lumps are not cancerous, but gps have strict guidelines on referring women on the two week fast track, it doesn’t mean you have breast cancer but there is a possibility which needs investigating. The waiting is the worst time, and it may be that even when you go to the clinic they can’t always give you any news there and then, but may take some biopsies and you will need to wait for the results again.  Just remember though that this forum is made up of women who are in the minority who get a breast cancer diagnosis after the tests, so don’t think that this will definitely be you ,  it’s just that a breast cancer forum is obviously biased towards breast cancer !  Hopefully you will get good news, but if you do get a breast cancer diagnosis, it is a very treatable disease nowadays and there are some outstanding drugs and other treatments which effectively “cure” most women - it’s not a pleasant journey, but doable, so just try and take a deep breath. Someone gave me good advice on here a long time ago, and that was to allow yourself time every day, whether that’s ten minute morning and night, or half an hour in the middle of the day, whatever you decide, and just try and spend that time thinking of what is happening to you, don’t spend any other time thinking about it. That helps you to gain a bit of control over the whole situation, at a time when you probably feel you are completely being blown about by your emotions. this forum is full of women who will try and help and try and ease your anxiety, so keep posting and reading. Posts.Title: ER+ and HER2+

Posts.Content: Hi Liz I was so similar to you - had lost weight but still overweight,  51 when I was diagnosed, no node involvement either. In terms of the chemo, I had weekly Paclitaxel (for twelve weeks every week) as my oncologist said I only needed the chemo in order to have the Herceptin. It is still chemo but the weekly one is a smaller dose each time. I was never sick or felt particularly sick, the steroids and anti-histamines they give you before the chemo caused me more problems! The chemo itself meant I lost my hair, my nose bled, I developed blisters on my hands and my fingers and toes became very sensitive. I developed an infection in my nails and nearly lost them all, I lost some toenails (including the big one five months after chemo) I wasn't aware of these side effects before, I was just indoctrinated to worry about the sickness which never materialised .... I am not sure about the fasting, you really need to see how you feel anyway and your tastebuds can go very weird! I was diagnosed just over a year ago and still having Herceptin (had no 15 last week) and am on Tamoxifen as am also ER+, but I can now see light at the end of the tunnel, my hair is growing back really well and my nails have fully recovered. Mentally I am not sure I am the same person (I know I'm not actually) but like to think I am a better version of the old me! Good luck with your next appointment, Jo x

Posts.Title: Everything

Posts.Content: Hi It would make sense that if you have DCIS 2 is the grade, as the "stage" for DCIS is 0,  it hasn't yet become invasive. It may also be that the area is larger than expected, which is why the mastectomy was suggested. BUT if when you were operated on they also discovered an invasive lump, this may have muddied the waters, so you do really need to know whether you have DCIS (pre-cancerous) or an invasive lump (cancerous) or both as there are different treatments after surgery depending on the type you have. Just for some context, i was initially told it was stage 1 grade 1, but when operated on this changed to stage 2 (lump bigger, just,  2cm) and grade 2, as the cells were more liable to reproduce than grade 1. They also uncovered a whole area of DCIS which didn't show up on any scans. My lump was ER+ and HER2+ so chemo, Herceptin and hormone tablets (no spread to any lymphs so not the full chem) The DCIS they only test for ER/PR+ as they do not give chemo for DCIS, so if I had just had the DCIS it would have been mastectomy and hormone treatmen, no chemo or radiotherapy. Your GP should have a copy of the pathology, so it may also be worth going to see them ? Hope this helps Jo x

Posts.Title: tamoxifen - hot flushes

Posts.Content: Hello I have been on Tamoxifen for 18 months now, my periods stopped when I started chemo and haven't restarted, but the chemo sent me into a chemical menopause, so I started with hot flushes during this time (at least being bald made for having a cool head!) I have had several different brands, and can't say I have noticed any difference between any of them. The hot flushes became worse after about 4-5 months on Tamoxifen, but this is due to them blocking the oestrogen, which is what they are supposed to do, so isn't a side effect but evidence of them working .... I tried acupuncture, and evening primrose oil, and eventually I acted on my oncologists recommendation of low dose citalopram. These have most definately helped the flushes, apparently they block the sensors which make you flush. I do however still find myself with sweat rolling down my face and body if I have over-exerted myself and it is hot, but I can cope with this, just the flushes which really affected me.  I have always had problems with my tendons, and my achilles and leg tendons are now quite stiff and I think this maybe the Tamoxifen, but I can get by with these problems. My mum had Tamoxifen a number of years ago and never had any issues at all, I think most ladies do, but when you feel like the side effects are affecting your life you are best seeking some help. Posts.Content: Hi Please try not to worry , finding DCIS when it is still that is the best prognosis there is , the surgery and treatment is to prevent it becoming stage 1 , or cancerous.  DCIS in itself can't spread , so with your diagnosis now the removal of the DCIS will be the cure and then other treatments offered after to help stop a recurrance. Posts.Content: Hi Mine was also ER+ and HER2+ , 2.1 cm grade 2 but extensive rupturing DCIS which were grade 3 , no lymph nodes involved.   DCIS isn't treated with chemo , so although grade 3 if no spread there is no need for chemo, it is only the invasive part which requires the chemo. I didn't need any other chemo apart from weekly Paclitaxel , which can only be given if there is no lymph nodes affected , so you may be offered that along with other chemo drugs for the invasive element being grade 3 ? I am currently on Tamoxifen but at 52 am borderline and may need my ovaries removing late this year. There is also a new drug which has not yet been given clearance by NICE called neratinib, which has very good results for HER2+ cancer , particularly where the cancer is also ER+ and has been authorised in the US - it is a follow up drug to Herceptin, so maybe by the time you have finished your year of Herceptin it will be available ? There are new treatments all the time, and although you get the double whammy of possible side effects being double positive  , you also get treatment targeted for both types of the cancer, which has to be a good thing. Posts.Title: Mammo 50

Posts.Content: Hi Stage depends on three different things , and within each of the different stages are different sub-stages , such as 2a. The three things are tumour size (T), node involvement (N) and metastatic status (M) DCIS is stage 0 as this is not a tumour , will have no node involvement (and the M status only applies to stage 4), A small tumour is classed as below 2cm, and with no node involvement will be classed as stage 1 etc. Until after the tumour has been removed it is just a very educated guess, mine was stage 1 but after removal changed to stage 2, grade 2 ,but they also found DCIS , grade 3 which didn't show up on any scans.  Please don't get too hung up on all this , everything before stage 4 is classed as "curable" no matter what your grade or stage there is a treatment for you - it just gives the specialists an idea of the treatment plan you should have. The actual pathology of the cancer gives many more different markers that relate to treatment. Everyone will have a slightly different cancer and treatment plan , try not to think too much about why one person has this and not that etc , that is for the oncologists and surgeons to decide.  It is like learning a new language, and is also hard to take everything on board at times , I was diagnosed a year ago and likened it to snakes and ladders, and a year on that is exactly how it has been.  Jo x
Posts.Title: Need some1 to talk please

Posts.Content: Hi there  I had a lumpectomy for invasive cancer , during which they found extensive nuclear grade DCIS- I ended up having two further margin shaves , the last one they got a margin but not big enough to be sure so am now having a mastectomy- my surgeon said the problem with DCIS is that it is impossible for them to see when operating so they are really using a (very educated) guess as the where it may be - I am glad I am having the mastectomy as this was what I originally wanted - am seeing the plastic surgeon on Tuesday.  I have found it really distressing at times having to make such huge decisions in such a short space of time , who knows if they are right at the time but I would just go with your gut and take your decision from there. Best wishes Jox
Posts.Title: Qustion re High Grade DCIS

Posts.Content: Hi It may be worth getting in touch with your local cancer charity and asking for their help ? My friends daughter was very upset when her dad developed bowel cancer and stopped going to school, she was 14/15 at the time. She got a lot of help and support from our local charity, so it may be worth asking if they can offer some advice ? There is also a list of resources on Cancer Research Uk here which may offer some help, and as GrannyLara says the Macmilllan helpline may be able to offer some help. It is a really rubbish time, my sons were 17, 18 and 20  when I was diagnosed and my husband was diagnosed the month after with prostate cancer - it felt like we were ripping their lives apart, and my middle son has gone off the rails (but I think he would have anyway) so I understand the guilt part completely. All I can say is that we just tried to laugh about some of the funnier moments, and we carried on at home as normal, I have always presented a positive outlook, they don't need my worries as well as their own. I really hope you find some help for your son, it is such a difficult age without the extra worry. Best wishes Jo x

Posts.Content: Hi i got up one morning and noticed hair on my pillow , I then ran my fingers through it and every time it was full of hair - the worst was washing it in the shower , it was like having a hair shower ! It can be quite distressing , I am not sure how long it took but I had mine all cut off which made life much easier , I didn't lose it all but lost most of it and guess it was a week from starting to when I had it all cut off and wore the wig x  it was weirdly liberating and it is now growing back - although curly  grey , am off for a number 3 all over this morning !  Just watch out for the signs , it doesn't all come out at once but does she's very quickly xx Best wishes jo x
Posts.Title: TAC and hair loss

Posts.Content: Hi there  I believe nuclear grade is like a Grade 3 in full blown cancer, fast growing - I'm having the mastectomy due to the DCIS , the invasive cancer was gone after the second operation , my DCIS wasn't visible on the mammogram or ultrasound and only discovered during my second operation - if the margins had been clear it may be that they would have missed the DCIS ? Who knows ?  My diagnosis went from small grade 1 lump, easily treatable and "just" lumpectomy and radiotherapy and  probably tamoxifen to now - grade 2, invasive is ER+ and HER2+ , extensive DCIS , three operations (plus more to come) 12 weekly chemo sessions and 18 herceptin injections every 3 weeks, tamoxifen for 10 years etc etc  So I know exactly what you mean, I am several months and lots of consultations down the line , but it is all bewildering at times.  When do you need to make your decision ? Jo xx
