Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic I know we have spoken several times over the past year or so - it is good you are generally feeling better and I wish I could say something which will make it completely better - do you think you can't allow yourself to move completely on because at the back of your mind , if it comes back, you think that will be a worse feeling and that it proved you were wrong to try and move on ? I have occasionally thought that myself , but it is always a fleeting thought and I can happily live my life, even with the permanent reminders of short hair, weird boob and side effects of Tamoxifen ... I think about cancer on a regular basis , but I can't change what will happen , so I am lucky to be able to just let cancer invade my day to day life momentarily. I wish I had the key to unlock whatever is causing you so much angst.  Tomorrow is another day and hopefully will be a good one for you. Much love Jo xx
Posts.Title: Down day

Posts.Content: Hi Charlene I have been on Tamoxifen for over a year now - I have had the same brand, RelonChem, since I started. Unfortunately I had chemotherapy so started with menopausal symptoms then, so I can't actually say whether the hot flushes and sweats are from the Tamoxifen or if I would have had them anyway.  My oncologist did a blood test last summer and said they were working well and there was nothing more than a trace of oestrogen in my body - the benefit for me is actually quite minimal, but I would rather take them than not. I have now started taking a mild anti-depressant, citraloprom which should ease the flushes, but I haven't had it long enough yet for them to be working properly. I think you should give them a go, the only person I know who refused the tablets got a recurrance last year and is gutted that she may have been able to stop it by taking the Tamoxifen. Jo x

Posts.Content: Hi Emma I was the same , I had an invasive lump with no clear margins and then they uncovered extensive DCIS, some erupting , and none of it visible on any scans so the third operation I had the surgeon was just guessing where it might be and still got no clear margins - so off for chemo and then mastectomy 8 weeks after the chemo , where the pathology showed there was no cancer left - but I was glad to be rid of the bloody thing to be honest , had an immediate implant reconstruction and perfectly happy with it.  I was really upset that they couldn't get clear margins and particularly after the second operation , but it is what it is and am now a year on with annual mammogram tomorrow... it can be quite a twisty path , I now just expect nothing from any of my appointments , just an open mind !  Jo x

Posts.Title: Moving Forward Course, Breast Cancer Care, anyone done the course

Posts.Content: Hi Moonbeam24 Just to add my experience to this .... I had a lumpectomy with no clear margins, due to extensive DCIS which was amongst the cancer. It hadn’t shown up on anything so the surgeon had to do the re-excision “blind” , still no clear margins so had a third op. Not enough clear margins for that op so had a mastectomy with an immediate implant. What I would say is that your own breast is far superior to any reconstruction,  I have a reminder of the whole process, and almost three years since diagnosis would like to be able to properly move on, except every time I see myself in the mirror I see nonnipple and a very odd “breast” Don’t get me wrong, I am perfectly fine 99% of the time, just those few times when I see myself.  I didn’t need radiotherapy as I had had a mastectomy, so that is a factor to consider that you may be in the same position - but deciding on reconstruction is very hard, however many women choose to stay flat , as did my mum, so you really have to weigh up the pros and cons for you. just as an aside when I had the pathology results of the mastectomy there was no trace of cancer or DCIS, so the last op had worked ..... Try and read up as much as you can on reconstruction and if possible speak to your BCN so that you have the best information for your decision. best of luck Jo

Posts.Content: Hi The oncotype dx test is only for women who are ER+ and HER2-, so wouldn’t be suitable for you. I was told I was HER2+ after the biopsy but after my WLE it came back negative. I was a bit puzzled by this and my surgeon queried it - it turned out to be a typing mistake and I was HER2+. I had weekly Paclitaxel for 12 weeks which is a lower dose of chemo  and allows (in the uk) for you to have Herceptin, and whilst there are still side effects they aren’t as intense as with some other chemo regimes. Posts.Title: Sore nose

Posts.Content: Hi It is such a horrible worrying time, but GP’s can’t diagnose breast cancer. What they can do is look at the evidence and if they feel there is a possibility there are strict guidelines to follow. I was referred to the fast track although my GP felt it wasn’t cancer, saw the GP Thursday and was at the breast clinic Monday morning. The consultant had a look and didn’t think it was too suspicious, but mammogram, ultrasound and biopsy done she then told me it was definitely breast cancer and that I would be coming back for a treatment plan. So even the consultants don’t know from just feeling a lump - 8 out 10 people who are referred don’t have breast cancer, but even if it is there are many thousands of women who had had treatment and are still here to tell the tale, it isn’t the death sentence it once was and there are some fantastic treatments available nowadays. I know you will be unbelievably anxious, and nothing anyone says will take that away until you have been - but often if biopsies are done there is another wait for results ( mine was unusual to be told there and then) and the waiting goes on... Hopefully you will be on this site for a very short time, but just take one step at a time and try and relax, my feeling was that if it is cancer then I have done the right thing being referred and I can’t change what the result may or may not be, so just tried to carry on as normal. Good luck Jo xx
